What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Extension of L1 Korean. Improved Korean speaking and conversational skills.
This course truly furthers your love for Korean. Professor Choi is incredibly passionate for the subject she teaches and that excitement everyday is reflected in the students.
Learned more Korean grammar, culture, and conversational skills

I expanded upon my knowledge of Korean by learning new vocabulary and grammar. It was nice to see how the grammar that we learned appeared in songs and cultural readings, which made me feel a greater sense of improvement in my Korean skills.
Learnt basic Korean grammar and vocabulary

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I feel like Korean was my most consistent and engaging class through Zoom. At the same time, I think there are just inherent limitations to using Zoom that go beyond the course that made the experience less ideal than if it were in person. It's kind of chaotic to have everyone repeat after the teacher over Zoom, but I guess there's no way around that. I also feel like it's tricky to "raise your hand" to ask a question over Zoom. 

I enjoyed still having the opportunity to meet with a TA every week, I felt like that continued to improve my Korean.
Strengths: Very interactive course, feedback for improvement was always quickly returned to the students to practice for the next class. Absolutely no weaknesses

Strengths: Lots of material in modules, good textbook, Choi SSN helped us correct common mistakes.
Weaknesses: Homeworks felt repetitive

The course is well structured in that it sticks to the syllabus and implements both the learning of and practice of the language by often splitting students into breakout rooms to converse to each other using the newly learned grammar and vocabulary. One of the weaknesses of this course is that the tests are very rushed; the professor shares her screen for the test and does not give students enough time before moving onto another questions. Because students work at different paces, I would like to suggest that the test be made on the quizzes section and just be shared with the students when the time comes so that we do not feel rushed when taking the tests.

Prof. Choi is a very caring and organised professor. She prepares worksheets for every lesson of the textbook, gives regular assignments, and gives clear feedback on homework. The only weakness were the sometimes open-ended homework assignments, that required too much creative work just to practise grammar.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Tests over Zoom was something that caught me a little off-guard. For this class in particular, they felt very fast and not enough time given to take a picture and upload. There was also one time that my computer just shut off in the middle of a test and that felt very stressful, especially since the tests were already so fast paced and I was afraid that I'd miss something. 

I did appreciate though that there wasn't an unbearable amount of homework every week, especially since we were already meeting every day. The course load felt very manageable during this time.
The live aspect of lecture really kept the students engaged and ready to learn
Breakout rooms were sometimes awkward, in-class screen sharing sometimes had issues, canvas modules well-organized but had frequent formatting issues

The online test format was a little hectic and disorientating. I often feel rushed on tests because I do not have control over the speed at which the questions are being presented and cannot check over my answers at the end because I do not have the question to reference. I do not think the share screen method works well for test-taking and would greatly prefer if each of the students had their own copy of the test so that they could go about the test at their own comfortable speed.
I found this class worked very well as a zoom lecture.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I love language learning and Korean is fun for me, so yes.

Yes I would. If you want to further your knowledge about the beautiful Korean culture and language, I would highly recommend this course. The department is so welcoming and incredibly passionate about the field they teach, and this love is directly reflected in the students
Yes, if you are interested in Korean language/culture and need another language credit.
Yes, I would recommend taking L2 Korean. It is a fun and easy language to pick up and everyday you'll feel a sense of improvement in your Korean.
Yes! If you are learning Korean, I strongly recommend taking a class with Prof. Choi.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: One Friday we had a recorded lecture but it was just as incredible as when we were having lecture live.
Korean Textbook and Lesson Modules
We had virtual seminars with occasional breakout room sessions.
